title: Standard Form of Hyperbola
text: The standard form for hyperbola is either $$\frac{{\left(x-h\right)}^2}{a^2}-\frac{{\left(y-k\right)}^2}{b^2}=1$$\nor $$\frac{{\left(y-k\right)}^2}{a^2}-\frac{{\left(x-h\right)}^2}{b^2}=1$$ depending on the transverse axis.
speech: The standard form for hyperbola is either  fraction, parentheses x minus h,  squared, over, a squared,  minus fraction, parentheses y minus k,  squared, over, b squared,  is equal to 1 \nor  fraction, parentheses y minus k,  squared, over, a squared,  minus fraction, parentheses x minus h,  squared, over, b squared,  is equal to 1  depending on the transverse axis.
pacedSpeech: The standard form for hyperbola is either   fraction,  x minus h,  squared, over, a squared,  minus fraction,  y minus k,  squared, over, b squared,  is equal to 1
or   fraction,  y minus k,  squared, over, a squared,  minus fraction,  x minus h,  squared, over, b squared,  is equal to 1
depending on the transverse axis.

title: Completing the Square
text: When there is an $$x^2$$ and $$x$$ term, we can complete the square to obtain an expression that is easier to work with. For $$a x^2+b x$$, we can re-express this as a*(x**2+b/a*x)=a*(x**2+b/a*x+(b/(2*a))**2-(b/(2*a))**2)=a*(x**2+b/a*x+(b/(2*a))**2)-a*(b/(2*a))**2)=a*(x+b/(2*a))**2-a*(b/(2*a))**2)
speech: When there is an  x squared  and  x  term, we can complete the square to obtain an expression that is easier to work with. For  a x squared plus b x , we can re-express this as a*(x**2+b/a*x)=a*(x**2+b/a*x+(b/(2*a))**2-(b/(2*a))**2)=a*(x**2+b/a*x+(b/(2*a))**2)-a*(b/(2*a))**2)=a*(x+b/(2*a))**2-a*(b/(2*a))**2)
pacedSpeech: When there is an   x squared
and   x
term, we can complete the square to obtain an expression that is easier to work with. For   a x squared plus b x

title: Completing the Square for $$x$$
text: In the equation, there is a $$-9x^2+18x$$. Note that $$a=-9$$ and $$b=18$$. What expression do we get after completing the square with the formula provided?

title: Completing the Square for $$y$$

title: Manipulating the Equation
text: If we are not able to tell directly whether an equation is a hyperbola using properties of the equation, we can attempt to force out a similar form to check.

title: Manipulating the Equation
text: Simplifying the equation with the two expression we found by completing the square, what is the expression on the LHS?

title: Manipulating the Equation
text: Next, we will move all the constant terms (9, $$-4$$, -14) to the RHS. What is value on the RHS?
speech: Next, we will move all the constant terms (9,  minus 4 , -14) to the RHS. What is value on the RHS?

title: Manipulating the Equation
text: We would want to make the RHS $$1$$. We can do so by dividing the equation by $$9$$ on both side.
speech: We would want to make the RHS  1 . We can do so by dividing the equation by  9,  on both side.
pacedSpeech: We would want to make the RHS   1
. We can do so by dividing the equation by   9,
on both side.

title: Manipulating the Equation
text: We observe that there is no coefficient on the numerator. This tells us we should remove the coefficient of $$x^2$$ and $$y^2$$. We can do so by dividing the denominator by the coefficient. We would thus divide the denominator $$9$$ by $$9$$ for the $$x^2$$ term and divide the denominator $$9$$ by $$1$$ for the $$y^2$$ term. What is the current expression?
speech: We observe that there is no coefficient on the numerator. This tells us we should remove the coefficient of  x squared  and  y squared . We can do so by dividing the denominator by the coefficient. We would thus divide the denominator  9  by  9  for the  x squared  term and divide the denominator  9  by  1  for the  y squared  term. What is the current expression?
